In Julia, Write a function `wrap_string`. It iterates over words and it will add a new line each time a maximum `text_width::Int=10` would be exceeded. Provide an example

Sure, here's how you can create a `wrap_string` function in Julia:

```julia
function wrap_string(string::String, text_width::Int=10)
    words = split(string)
    current_line = ""
    wrapped_string = ""

    for word in words
        if length(current_line) + length(word) + 1 > text_width
            wrapped_string *= current_line * "\n"
            current_line = word
        else
            if !isempty(current_line)
                current_line *= " "
            end
            current_line *= word
        end
    end

    wrapped_string *= current_line
    return wrapped_string
end
```

This function splits the input string into words and then iterates over each word. If adding the current word to the current line would exceed the maximum text width, it starts a new line. Otherwise, it adds the word to the current line.

Here's how you can use this function:

```julia
text = "This is a sample text that needs to be wrapped."
wrapped_text = wrap_string(text, 15)
println(wrapped_text)
```

This will output:

```
This is a
sample text
that needs to
be wrapped.
```

Each line is no longer than 15 characters.
